headline: Trump's Endorsement of J.D. Vance Worries Advisers Who Fear He's Backing Losers

That fixation apparently goes both ways: in a recent interview with the Post, Trump said Rep. Mo Brooks lost his backing in the Alabama Senate race specifically because he got off the 2020 election fraud.?
In backing Vance, Trump ignored the advice of some of his adviserswho are working for other candidates in the race,? according to the Post.

A week after the former president reportedly stunned some advisers and deepened intra-party tensions by endorsing celebrity physician Mehmet Oz for Pennsylvania's open Senate seat, Trump doled out yet another controversial endorsement, this time to Hillbilly Elegy author, venture capitalist, and Twitter provocateur J.D.

In Friday's statement, Trump called Vance strong on the Border, tough on Crime?and a warrior on the Rigged and Stolen Presidential Election.? (The 2020 presidential election was neither rigged nor stolen, but Trump has turned blind fealty to these false statements into a litmus test for Republicans seeking his favor.)

Vance's rivals, including former state treasurer and MAGA convert Josh Mandel, were among the swath of Ohio Republicans who tried to persuade Trump to choose differently amid reports that he was leaning toward Vance, whose hard-right pivot has been complicated by his history of criticizing Trump.

The paper added, Trump received so many calls that he stopped taking them Friday.?
In addition to the GOP primaries in Ohio and Pennsylvania, Trump's image is also on the line in Georgia, where he has endorsed gubernatorial candidate David Perdue, who is trailing incumbent Brian Kemp.

Trump was reportedly concerned about Vance's standing in the polls (he has trailed in many) but was cheered by, among other things, Vance being good on TVa key factor in Trump's Oz endorsementand his policy positions, according to Politico.

Some Trump advisers fear he has diluted his endorsements by backing hundreds of candidates, some for low-level positions, because of their willingness to support his false claims of a fraudulent election,? according to the Post.

Trump is reportedly willing to bet on Vance because he thinks his endorsement will propel the candidate to victory, a risky strategy that could jeopardize his own place in the party ahead of November's midterms.

is the most likely to take out the weak, but dangerous, Democrat opponentdangerous because they will have so much money to spend,? Trump said of Rep. Tim Ryan, the likely Democratic nominee in the race for Sen.
Vance's supporters include billionaire Peter Thiel, Fox News opinion host Tucker Carlson, and Trump's son, Donald Trump Jr., all of whom reportedly lobbied on his behalf.
Trump's willingness to test his effect on the party by injecting himself into state contests could be a boon to his potential rivals in the 2024 presidential race.
Vance may have said some not so great things about me in the past, but he gets it now, and I have seen that in spades,? Trump said in a statement Friday evening.
Donald Trump kicked off the weekend by announcing his pick for another high-profile GOP primary, on which he is betting his own political capital.
If he loses in Pennsylvania and he loses in Georgia, you have a much weaker Trump in 2024,? one person from a rival camp told the Post.
This is not an easy endorsement for me to make because I like and respect some of the other candidates in this race,? Trump added.
I'm a gambler,? Trump reportedly told an adviser as he explained his desire to wade into the Pennsylvania race.
Some of his advisers believe this is a mistake, the Washington Post reported Saturday.
